description: From Middle French pacte, from Old French, from Latin pactum (“something agreed upon”), from paciscere (“to agree”).

entries.meaning: An agreement; a compact; a covenant.
examples: New sisters at the sorority have to agree to the pact set out by the former members.

entries.meaning: (international law) An agreement between two or more nations

verbs.description: pact (third-person singular simple present pacts, present participle pacting, simple past and past participle pacted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To form a pact; to agree formally.
examples: When national elites pacted in Mexico, they pacted to the advantage of the elites as against the masses and also to the advantage of the center as against the provinces.
